Award.AwardTitle: EAPSI: The relationship between trait distributions and environmental conditions in a tropical forest plot in southwest China

ProgramReference.Text: US CHINA COOP IN BASIC SCIENCE

POR.DRECONTENT:
I studied 22 species of fig trees (genus: Ficus, family: Moraceae) in Xishuangbanna, China. These 22 species are all found within a 20-ha (about 50 acre) forest plot where all trees are mapped, identified, and measured. In addition to these 22 fig species, there are at least 300 other species of trees all coexisting in the plot. Why don't some species become more successful and drive out the others? In a similar sized plot in Wisconsin there are only 36 total species. Why are there so many more species in tropical regions? Ecologists have long been challenged to explain and demonstrate why so many species co-exist in tropical forests. We studied figs because they are the most diverse genus on the plot in Xishuangbanna. I collaborated on this project with Dr. Tang Yong of the Xishuangbanna Tropical Botanical Garden.

One way ecologists have studied the mechanisms of co-existence is by studying the traits of species found living together. It is hypothesized that when co-existing species have very different traits from one another (for example, neighboring trees might have very different leaf sizes) that competition among species with similar traits is strong. Thus species are able to co-exist by being very different from each other and not competing for the same resources. On the other hand, if co-existing species have very similar traits it is thought that the environment is acting as a filter to remove species that do poorly in that environment. In this case, many species co-exist across the forest because the underlying environment varies and favors different species in different places.

We tested these hypotheses in Xishuangbanna among the 22 species of figs. We collected data on 5 traits that we think are ecologically important to figs. We found that co-existing species had traits that were highly similar to each other, or were very different from each other, depending on the method we used to measure similarity. This finding means that we and other ecologists need to work to determine which measurements of trait similarity are most ecologically important. We also found that one trait showed the strongest patterns of similarity among co-existing species: specific leaf area, which is related to the photosynthetic capacity of species. Specific leaf area has been widely recognized as an important trait affecting species performance in different environments. Our finding confirms its importance even within a group of closely related species.

This research contributes to our understanding of how species co-exist and how communities of species come together. This understanding is necessary in order to predict the future responses of ecosystems to man-made environmental change. Prior to going to Xishuangbanna, I visited 7 classes of middle school science students in Austin, Texas. I introduced to them the amazing wildlife of southeast Asian rainforests. Over the summer while I was in Xishuangbanna I answered these students questions on a blog where I also posted photos and summarized my work (http://se-asia-jesselasky.blogspot.com/). While at Xishuangbanna, I gave a free day-long seminar in the use of a free, open-source statistical software (R) for students and professors.
